ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: By working on an empirical project, I vastly improved my Stata skills and learned how to use LaTex in combination with Stata (i.e. importing plots and tables). Through the literature review portion of my project, I got to read a number of papers on the topic of my project and on adjacent topics, which broadened my knowledge of labor economics.

This class is the perfect extension of Private Equity Investing. Through textbook readings from Professor Schmertzler, independent book readings, and discussions with company executives, this course was an amazing introduction to early stage investing.
Early-stage investments principles, skills, and applications
Extremely detailed, technical and well-explained insights into how to invest in - and by proxy, build - successful early and growth stage businesses.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: this is a really great opportunity to learn about the research process and to study a particular topic in economics in depth. Weekly meetings with the professor helped provide structure. No particular weaknesses that I can think of.

This course was absolutely amazing. Professor Schmertzler has a unique ability to synthesize complex industry information in an academic setting. The only thing I would change is being able to meet and learn more.
Strengths - loved taking the class with Professor Schmertzler

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you're looking to study a highly specific sub-field of economics or to learn more about the research process more generally, this is a really great opportunity. I assume that how much you get out of the course will depend to some extent on the professor that you work with; I was lucky to take the course with Professor O'Dea, who's incredibly knowledgeable, explains things very clearly, and was committed to making sure I was learning and getting something out of the experience.

Absolutely. If you're interesting in finance, particularly early stage investing, this is a must take course. I've learned so much about the industry and about myself through Professor Schmertzler. It 100% will make me better as I start work.
Yes - if you can take it with a professor you've had great experiences with, it can be a phenomenal learning experience
Whole-heartedly, whether offered in its current format or as a formally established course.
